sn11.3:4.2: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
sn11.3:5.1: “Once upon a time, mendicants, a battle was fought between the gods and the demons.
sn11.3:5.2: Then Sakka, the Lord of Gods, addressed the gods of the Thirty-three:
sn11.3:6.1: ‘Good sirs, when the gods are fighting, if you get scared or terrified, just look up at my banner’s crest.
sn11.3:6.2: Then your fear and terror will go away.
sn11.3:7.1: If you can’t see my banner’s crest, then look up at banner’s crest of Pajāpati, king of gods.
sn11.3:7.2: Then your fear and terror will go away.
sn11.3:8.1: If you can’t see his banner’s crest, then look up at banner’s crest of Varuṇa, king of gods.
sn11.3:8.2: Then your fear and terror will go away.
sn11.3:9.1: If you can’t see his banner’s crest, then look up at banner’s crest of Īsāna, king of gods.
sn11.3:9.2: Then your fear and terror will go away.’
sn11.3:10.1: However, when they look up at those banner’s crests their fear and terror might go away or it might not.
sn11.3:11.2: Because Sakka is not free of greed, hate, and delusion. He gets fearful, scared, terrified, and runs away.
sn11.3:12.2: If you’ve gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut and you get scared or terrified, just recollect me:
sn11.3:12.3: ‘That Blessed One is perfect, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme trainer of people, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
sn11.3:12.4: Then your fear and terror will go away.
sn11.3:13.1: If you can’t recollect me, then recollect the teaching:
sn11.3:13.2: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—realizable in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.’
sn11.3:13.3: Then your fear and terror will go away.
sn11.3:14.1: If you can’t recollect the teaching, then recollect the Saṅgha:
sn11.3:14.2: ‘The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is practicing the way that’s good, straightforward, principled, and proper. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individuals. This Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a teacher’s offering, and worthy of greeting with folded palms. It is a supreme field of merit for the world.’
sn11.3:14.3: Then your fear and terror will go away.
sn11.3:15.2: Because the Realized One is free of greed, hate, and delusion. He does not get fearful, scared, terrified, or run away.”
sn11.3:15.3: This is what the Buddha said.
sn11.3:15.4: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
sn11.3:16.1: “In the wilderness, at a tree’s root,
sn11.3:16.2: or an empty hut, O mendicants,
sn11.3:16.4: and no fear will come to you.
sn11.3:17.1: If you can’t recollect the Buddha—
sn11.3:17.2: the eldest in the world, the bull of a man—
sn11.3:18.1: If you can’t recollect the teaching—
sn11.3:19.2: the teaching, and the Saṅgha, mendicants,
sn11.3:19.4: and goosebumps will be no more.”
